meanings.def: rather; to some extent
examples: These trousers are a bit tight.
‘Are you tired?’ ‘Yes, I am a bit.’
I was a bit disappointed by the film.
It costs a bit more than I wanted to spend.
The future looks a little bit brighter this morning.
I felt a wee bit guilty about it.
I can lend you fifty pounds, if you want. That should help a bit.
These shoes are a bit tight.
I’ll be a bit later home tomorrow.
Can you turn the volume up a bit?
These shoes are a little bit too tight.
I’ll be a little later home tomorrow.
Can you turn the volume up a little bit?
I'm still just a bit confused.
He helped me a little bit in the afternoon.

meanings.def: a short time or distance
examples: Wait a bit!
Can you move up a bit?
for a bit Greg thought for a bit before answering.
in a bit See you in a bit.

meanings.def: a small amount or piece of something
examples: Here are some useful bits of information.
I have a bit of good news for you.
Let me give you a little bit of advice.
With a bit of luck, we'll be there by 12.
I've got a bit of shopping to do.
bits of paper/wood/plastic
Here's a bit of news that may interest you.
Do you want a bit of pizza?
Can you save me a bit?
A big bit of plaster just fell down from the ceiling.
She tore the letter up and threw it on the floor. Marion stooped to pick up the bits.
I've bought a nice bit of fish for dinner.
I'm worried because bits keep falling off my car.
He managed to get odd bits of work, but no regular job.

meanings.def: a part of something larger
examples: The best bit of the holiday was seeing the Grand Canyon.
I read it, but I missed out the boring bits.
bit about something I like the bit about owls in the first chapter.
Listen to the interview again and pick out the bits you want to use in the article.
The school play was a huge success—the audience roared with laughter at all the funny bits.

meanings.def: a large amount
examples: ‘How much does he earn?’ ‘Quite a bit!’
It rained a fair bit during the night.
The new system will take a bit of getting used to (= it will take a long time to get used to).
‘Has it been difficult for you at work?’ ‘Just a bit (= it has been very difficult).’
We made a good bit of progress.

meanings.def: the smallest unit of information used by a computer
a metal bar that is put in a horse’s mouth so that the rider can control it
a tool or part of a tool for drilling (= making) holes
an amount of money equal to 12½ cents
a person’s sexual organs
to be very sad or worried
examples: Inside I'm in bits because I miss him so much.
I’m in bits about the problems I’ve had.
She was in bits over her decision to quit.

meanings.def: behaviour or ideas that are typical of a particular group, type of person or activity
examples: She couldn't accept the whole drug-culture bit.

meanings.def: a piece at a time; gradually
examples: He assembled the model aircraft bit by bit.
Bit by bit memories of the night came back to me.

meanings.def: not fair or not reasonable
examples: It's a bit much calling me at three in the morning.
The noise from next door is getting a bit much.

meanings.def: used when talking about unpleasant or negative things or ideas, to mean ‘rather a…’
examples: We may have a bit of a problem on our hands.
The rail strike is a bit of a pain.

meanings.def: a person that you think is sexually attractive
examples: Dave’s new girlfriend is a bit of all right, isn’t she?

meanings.def: a person of a low social class who has a sexual relationship with somebody of a higher class
the boyfriend or girlfriend of somebody who is already married or in a steady sexual relationship with somebody else
examples: Is he your bit on the side?

meanings.def: small objects or items of various kinds
examples: She stuffed all her bits and pieces into a bag and left.
I just need to get a few bits and pieces at the supermarket.

meanings.def: to use bombs or other weapons to destroy somebody/something completely
examples: The plane was blown to pieces when the bomb exploded.

meanings.def: impatient to do or start doing something
examples: Gerry’s champing at the bit to go to college.

meanings.def: to do your share of a task
examples: We can finish this job on time if everyone does their bit.

meanings.def: just as good, bad, etc.; equally good, bad, etc.
examples: Rome is every bit as beautiful as Paris.
He’s every bit as clever as she is.

meanings.def: to become very enthusiastic about something that you have started to do so that you are unlikely to stop until you have finished
not at all; not in any way
examples: ‘Are you cold?’ ‘Not a bit.’
It's not a bit of use (= there's no point in) complaining.
I'm not the least bit interested in football.
I don't like that idea one bit.

meanings.def: used for saying that something that you had expected to happen did not happen
examples: You'd think she'd be tired after the journey but not a bit of it!

meanings.def: not any
examples: He didn't take a blind bit of notice of me (= he ignored me).
It won't make the blindest bit of difference (= it will make no difference at all).

meanings.def: not at all
examples: Normally I'm not the least bit shy.
He wasn't the slightest bit interested in answering our questions.

meanings.def: into small pieces
examples: The book fell to bits in my hands.
All the crockery had been smashed to bits.
She took the engine to bits, then carefully put it together again.

meanings.def: very much
examples: I love my kids to bits.
She was thrilled to bits when I said I'd come.
